bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 31, 1947

div1.p: Truby completes the questionnaires sent by Hench. He refers to two newspaper clippings citing another yellow fever collaborator, and suggests that Hench read several chapters in a book about Victor Vaughan.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 31, 1947

opener.dateline:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Mch.- 31/47

div1.p:
Your letter of the 19th is
here. You inclosed one written on Feb 20
also and stated you had held that one in
order to inclose a letter from Lambert. You
failed to inclose it however.

I am glad you rec'd the express package.
I was somewhat worried because you
had not acknowledged receipt of the package
and you failed to answer my air mail
letter of Mch. 3 telling you I had sent the
package by express. That letter sums up
my opinion on the important things we
discussed and also some remarks on
the Ambulance picture of Reed at Camp
Lazear. I think I have identified most
of the men in the picture. I wish you
would write to Dr Frost at once to see
if you can't locate Mrs. Jernegan. I
gave you his address in the typed answers.

If you did not get that letter I will
send you my retained copy. I would
like brief comment on the things in that
letter. It won't take longer and I might
be able to dig up more info. before
Ac
T
2
I go East.

I will be able to look over the
printed copies of the microfilms if you
send them promptly. I expect to leave here
May 8.

I know you will have plenty of
comments on my answers to your 3
questionnaires. So when you write them,
leave space after each paragraph and
I will write in my answers.comment. That is
easier for me than getting a stenographer
for I can't dictate long at a time
because they all work so late in town and by
the time they get here it is nearly my dinner
time. I don't work on yf after dark. That
is the time the mosquitoes might pester me
you know. I am anxious to make any-
thing clear that you find questionable- Of
course that is going to be a big job for you
and it will have to wait until you
have time to do it.

I am inclosing two newspaper clippings
of interest. The one about Dr. Mazzuri
shows another new manhero(deceased) who is trying to
“Climb Aboard the Band Wagon (Reed's) after the
battle is over”- I never met Mazzuri but he
was at Camp Columbia in 1901- It is possible that
he did assist Ames in the Huts. Possibly he is
the man Lambert took for Pinto- It is
important to find out when he arrived at
Camp Columbia. He was not there before
Nov. 30, 1900, when I left there- He was a
Capt. of Vols. see Gen Wood's report for 1901-
3-
Thanks for the Thumb-nail sketches by
Dr Frost. They are fine but Dr-
Durham has swallowed Hammeter's report
on Carroll completely. He also quotes
extensively from any book, but does
not refer to it- Dr. Frost quotes, too,
but gives me credit.

I have been fortunate in finding
something good on Dr-Echeveria in Dr
Victor Vaughan “Memories of a Doctor”
p 350- You had better read that whole
chapter and also the next one on the
Typhoid Commission before you write
your book. Dr Vaughan was another of
my very fine friends- We had near by desks
in the S. Q. O in the Division of Sanitation in
World War I- I think I told you of the above in 1943.

Referring to Jernegan again I believe
he is the man in the Ambulance picture.
If so then 16 in the Det. picture is not Jernegan
and so it is important to investigate further.
Jernegan was a larger man than Lawrence (16)
Mrs Stark might recognize Jernegan in the
Ambulance picture. The Starks knew him well.
Mrs Jernegan, if not living, had rare a son
that Dr Frost knew. On p. 15, Thumbnail Sketches,
Dr. Davison speaks of him. Get after
this, it is important.

Nothing yet from Mrs Gilhus. I will see
her soon.

I would like to see Dr Beverly & Lambert's
letters in reply to yours. Will return them
promptly-

I have held this for several days as
this is the week, I think, when you are
away on your lecture tour.

Mrs Truby & Elizabeth join me
in cordial regards for you & Mrs
Hench-
